service.name: Amazon Simple Email Service
service.documentation: Amazon Simple Email Service (Amazon SES) is a cost-effective outbound-only email-sending service built on the reliable and scalable infrastructure that Amazon.com has developed to serve its own customer base. With Amazon SES, you can send transactional email, marketing messages, or any other type of high-quality content and you only pay for what you use. Along with high deliverability, Amazon SES provides easy, real-time access to your sending statistics and built-in notifications for bounces, complaints, and deliveries to help you fine-tune your email-sending strategy.

cabal.name: Amazon Simple Email Service
cabal.description: Amazon Simple Email Service (Amazon SES) is a cost-effective outbound-only email-sending service built on the reliable and scalable infrastructure that Amazon.com has developed to serve its own customer base. With Amazon SES, you can send transactional email, marketing messages, or any other type of high-quality content and you only pay for what you use. Along with high deliverability, Amazon SES provides easy, real-time access to your sending statistics and built-in notifications for bounces, complaints, and deliveries to help you fine-tune your email-sending strategy.

optional.name: _dCcAddresses
optional.documentation: The CC: field(s) of the message.

optional.name: _dBccAddresses

required.name: _idaDkimEnabled
required.documentation: True if DKIM signing is enabled for email sent from the identity; false otherwise.

required.name: _idaDkimVerificationStatus
required.documentation: Describes whether Amazon SES has successfully verified the DKIM DNS records (tokens) published in the domain name's DNS. (This only applies to domain identities, not email address identities.)

optional.name: _idaDkimTokens
optional.documentation:
A set of character strings that represent the domain's identity. Using these tokens, you will need to create DNS CNAME records that point to DKIM public keys hosted by Amazon SES. Amazon Web Services will eventually detect that you have updated your DNS records; this detection process may take up to 72 hours. Upon successful detection, Amazon SES will be able to DKIM-sign email originating from that domain. (This only applies to domain identities, not email address identities.)

For more information about creating DNS records using DKIM tokens, go to the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

fields.name: _idaDkimEnabled
fields.documentation: True if DKIM signing is enabled for email sent from the identity; false otherwise.

fields.name: _idaDkimTokens
fields.documentation:
A set of character strings that represent the domain's identity. Using these tokens, you will need to create DNS CNAME records that point to DKIM public keys hosted by Amazon SES. Amazon Web Services will eventually detect that you have updated your DNS records; this detection process may take up to 72 hours. Upon successful detection, Amazon SES will be able to DKIM-sign email originating from that domain. (This only applies to domain identities, not email address identities.)

For more information about creating DNS records using DKIM tokens, go to the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

fields.name: _idaDkimVerificationStatus
fields.documentation: Describes whether Amazon SES has successfully verified the DKIM DNS records (tokens) published in the domain name's DNS. (This only applies to domain identities, not email address identities.)

optional.name: _bText
optional.documentation: The content of the message, in text format. Use this for text-based email clients, or clients on high-latency networks (such as mobile devices).

optional.name: _bHtml
optional.documentation: The content of the message, in HTML format. Use this for email clients that can process HTML. You can include clickable links, formatted text, and much more in an HTML message.

fields.name: _bHtml

fields.name: _bText

field.name: _rmData
field.documentation:
The raw data of the message. The client must ensure that the message format complies with Internet email standards regarding email header fields, MIME types, MIME encoding, and base64 encoding (if necessary).

The To:, CC:, and BCC: headers in the raw message can contain a group list.

For more information, go to the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

required.name: _rmData
required.documentation:
The raw data of the message. The client must ensure that the message format complies with Internet email standards regarding email header fields, MIME types, MIME encoding, and base64 encoding (if necessary).

The To:, CC:, and BCC: headers in the raw message can contain a group list.

For more information, go to the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

operations.name: DeleteIdentity
operations.documentation:
Deletes the specified identity (email address or domain) from the list of verified identities.

This action is throttled at one request per second.

field.name: _diIdentity
field.documentation: The identity to be removed from the list of identities for the AWS Account.

operations.name: DeleteVerifiedEmailAddress
operations.documentation:
Deletes the specified email address from the list of verified addresses.

The DeleteVerifiedEmailAddress action is deprecated as of the May 15, 2012 release of Domain Verification. The DeleteIdentity action is now preferred.

This action is throttled at one request per second.

optional.documentation: The DKIM attributes for an email address or a domain.

fields.name: _gidarDkimAttributes
fields.documentation: The DKIM attributes for an email address or a domain.

operations.name: GetIdentityDkimAttributes
operations.documentation:
Returns the current status of Easy DKIM signing for an entity. For domain name identities, this action also returns the DKIM tokens that are required for Easy DKIM signing, and whether Amazon SES has successfully verified that these tokens have been published.

This action takes a list of identities as input and returns the following information for each:

  • Whether Easy DKIM signing is enabled or disabled.
  • A set of DKIM tokens that represent the identity. If the identity is an email address, the tokens represent the domain of that address.
  • Whether Amazon SES has successfully verified the DKIM tokens published in the domain's DNS. This information is only returned for domain name identities, not for email addresses.

This action is throttled at one request per second.

For more information about creating DNS records using DKIM tokens, go to the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

field.name: _gidaIdentities
field.documentation: A list of one or more verified identities - email addresses, domains, or both.

operations.name: GetIdentityNotificationAttributes
operations.documentation:
Given a list of verified identities (email addresses and/or domains), returns a structure describing identity notification attributes.

This action is throttled at one request per second.

For more information about using notifications with Amazon SES, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

operations.name: GetIdentityVerificationAttributes
operations.documentation:
Given a list of identities (email addresses and/or domains), returns the verification status and (for domain identities) the verification token for each identity.

This action is throttled at one request per second.

optional.name: _givaIdentities

Returns the user's current sending limits.

This action is throttled at one request per second.

field.name: _gssrSendDataPoints
field.documentation: A list of data points, each of which represents 15 minutes of activity.

optional.name: _gssrSendDataPoints
optional.documentation: A list of data points, each of which represents 15 minutes of activity.

fields.name: _gssrSendDataPoints
fields.documentation: A list of data points, each of which represents 15 minutes of activity.

operations.name: GetSendStatistics
operations.documentation:
Returns the user's sending statistics. The result is a list of data points, representing the last two weeks of sending activity.

Each data point in the list contains statistics for a 15-minute interval.

This action is throttled at one request per second.

operations.name: ListIdentities
operations.documentation:
Returns a list containing all of the identities (email addresses and domains) for a specific AWS Account, regardless of verification status.

This action is throttled at one request per second.

optional.name: _liIdentityType
optional.documentation: The type of the identities to list. Possible values are "EmailAddress" and "Domain". If this parameter is omitted, then all identities will be listed.

optional.name: _liNextToken
optional.documentation: The token to use for pagination.

optional.name: _liMaxItems
optional.documentation: The maximum number of identities per page. Possible values are 1-100 inclusive.

fields.name: _liIdentityType
fields.documentation: The type of the identities to list. Possible values are "EmailAddress" and "Domain". If this parameter is omitted, then all identities will be listed.

fields.name: _liMaxItems
fields.documentation: The maximum number of identities per page. Possible values are 1-100 inclusive.

fields.name: _liNextToken
fields.documentation: The token to use for pagination.

field.name: _lvearVerifiedEmailAddresses
field.documentation: A list of email addresses that have been verified.

optional.documentation: A list of email addresses that have been verified.

fields.name: _lvearVerifiedEmailAddresses
fields.documentation: A list of email addresses that have been verified.

operations.name: ListVerifiedEmailAddresses
operations.documentation:
Returns a list containing all of the email addresses that have been verified.

The ListVerifiedEmailAddresses action is deprecated as of the May 15, 2012 release of Domain Verification. The ListIdentities action is now preferred.

This action is throttled at one request per second.

field.name: _serMessageId
field.documentation: The unique message identifier returned from the SendEmail action.

required.name: _serMessageId
required.documentation: The unique message identifier returned from the SendEmail action.

fields.name: _serMessageId
fields.documentation: The unique message identifier returned from the SendEmail action.

operations.name: SendEmail
operations.documentation:
Composes an email message based on input data, and then immediately queues the message for sending.

You can only send email from verified email addresses and domains. If you have not requested production access to Amazon SES, you must also verify every recipient email address except for the recipients provided by the Amazon SES mailbox simulator. For more information, go to the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

The total size of the message cannot exceed 10 MB.

Amazon SES has a limit on the total number of recipients per message: The combined number of To:, CC: and BCC: email addresses cannot exceed 50. If you need to send an email message to a larger audience, you can divide your recipient list into groups of 50 or fewer, and then call Amazon SES repeatedly to send the message to each group.

For every message that you send, the total number of recipients (To:, CC: and BCC:) is counted against your sending quota - the maximum number of emails you can send in a 24-hour period. For information about your sending quota, go to the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

required.name: _seSource
required.documentation:
The identity's email address.

By default, the string must be 7-bit ASCII. If the text must contain any other characters, then you must use MIME encoded-word syntax (RFC 2047) instead of a literal string. MIME encoded-word syntax uses the following form: =?charset?encoding?encoded-text?=. For more information, see RFC 2047.

required.name: _seDestination
required.documentation: The destination for this email, composed of To:, CC:, and BCC: fields.

required.name: _seMessage
required.documentation: The message to be sent.

optional.name: _seReplyToAddresses
optional.documentation: The reply-to email address(es) for the message. If the recipient replies to the message, each reply-to address will receive the reply.

optional.name: _seReturnPath
optional.documentation: The email address to which bounces and complaints are to be forwarded when feedback forwarding is enabled. If the message cannot be delivered to the recipient, then an error message will be returned from the recipient's ISP; this message will then be forwarded to the email address specified by the ReturnPath parameter.

fields.name: _seDestination
fields.documentation: The destination for this email, composed of To:, CC:, and BCC: fields.

fields.name: _seMessage
fields.documentation: The message to be sent.

fields.name: _seReplyToAddresses
fields.documentation: The reply-to email address(es) for the message. If the recipient replies to the message, each reply-to address will receive the reply.

fields.name: _seReturnPath
fields.documentation: The email address to which bounces and complaints are to be forwarded when feedback forwarding is enabled. If the message cannot be delivered to the recipient, then an error message will be returned from the recipient's ISP; this message will then be forwarded to the email address specified by the ReturnPath parameter.

fields.name: _seSource
fields.documentation:
The identity's email address.

By default, the string must be 7-bit ASCII. If the text must contain any other characters, then you must use MIME encoded-word syntax (RFC 2047) instead of a literal string. MIME encoded-word syntax uses the following form: =?charset?encoding?encoded-text?=. For more information, see RFC 2047.

field.name: _srerMessageId
field.documentation: The unique message identifier returned from the SendRawEmail action.

required.name: _srerMessageId
required.documentation: The unique message identifier returned from the SendRawEmail action.

fields.name: _srerMessageId
fields.documentation: The unique message identifier returned from the SendRawEmail action.

operations.name: SendRawEmail
operations.documentation:
Sends an email message, with header and content specified by the client. The SendRawEmail action is useful for sending multipart MIME emails. The raw text of the message must comply with Internet email standards; otherwise, the message cannot be sent.

You can only send email from verified email addresses and domains. If you have not requested production access to Amazon SES, you must also verify every recipient email address except for the recipients provided by the Amazon SES mailbox simulator. For more information, go to the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

The total size of the message cannot exceed 10 MB. This includes any attachments that are part of the message.

Amazon SES has a limit on the total number of recipients per message: The combined number of To:, CC: and BCC: email addresses cannot exceed 50. If you need to send an email message to a larger audience, you can divide your recipient list into groups of 50 or fewer, and then call Amazon SES repeatedly to send the message to each group.

The To:, CC:, and BCC: headers in the raw message can contain a group list. Note that each recipient in a group list counts towards the 50-recipient limit.

For every message that you send, the total number of recipients (To:, CC: and BCC:) is counted against your sending quota - the maximum number of emails you can send in a 24-hour period. For information about your sending quota, go to the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

required.name: _sreRawMessage
required.documentation:
The raw text of the message. The client is responsible for ensuring the following:

  • Message must contain a header and a body, separated by a blank line.
  • All required header fields must be present.
  • Each part of a multipart MIME message must be formatted properly.
  • MIME content types must be among those supported by Amazon SES. For more information, go to the Amazon SES Developer Guide.
  • Content must be base64-encoded, if MIME requires it.

optional.name: _sreSource
optional.documentation:
The identity's email address.

By default, the string must be 7-bit ASCII. If the text must contain any other characters, then you must use MIME encoded-word syntax (RFC 2047) instead of a literal string. MIME encoded-word syntax uses the following form: =?charset?encoding?encoded-text?=. For more information, see RFC 2047.

optional.name: _sreDestinations
optional.documentation: A list of destinations for the message, consisting of To:, CC:, and BCC: addresses.

fields.name: _sreDestinations
fields.documentation: A list of destinations for the message, consisting of To:, CC:, and BCC: addresses.

fields.name: _sreRawMessage
fields.documentation:
The raw text of the message. The client is responsible for ensuring the following:

  • Message must contain a header and a body, separated by a blank line.
  • All required header fields must be present.
  • Each part of a multipart MIME message must be formatted properly.
  • MIME content types must be among those supported by Amazon SES. For more information, go to the Amazon SES Developer Guide.
  • Content must be base64-encoded, if MIME requires it.

fields.name: _sreSource
fields.documentation:
The identity's email address.

By default, the string must be 7-bit ASCII. If the text must contain any other characters, then you must use MIME encoded-word syntax (RFC 2047) instead of a literal string. MIME encoded-word syntax uses the following form: =?charset?encoding?encoded-text?=. For more information, see RFC 2047.

operations.name: SetIdentityDkimEnabled
operations.documentation:
Enables or disables Easy DKIM signing of email sent from an identity:

  • If Easy DKIM signing is enabled for a domain name identity (e.g., example.com), then Amazon SES will DKIM-sign all email sent by addresses under that domain name (e.g., user@example.com).
  • If Easy DKIM signing is enabled for an email address, then Amazon SES will DKIM-sign all email sent by that email address.

For email addresses (e.g., user@example.com), you can only enable Easy DKIM signing if the corresponding domain (e.g., example.com) has been set up for Easy DKIM using the AWS Console or the VerifyDomainDkim action.

This action is throttled at one request per second.

For more information about Easy DKIM signing, go to the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

required.name: _sideIdentity
required.documentation: The identity for which DKIM signing should be enabled or disabled.

required.name: _sideDkimEnabled
required.documentation: Sets whether DKIM signing is enabled for an identity. Set to true to enable DKIM signing for this identity; false to disable it.

fields.name: _sideDkimEnabled
fields.documentation: Sets whether DKIM signing is enabled for an identity. Set to true to enable DKIM signing for this identity; false to disable it.

fields.name: _sideIdentity
fields.documentation: The identity for which DKIM signing should be enabled or disabled.

operations.name: SetIdentityFeedbackForwardingEnabled
operations.documentation:
Given an identity (email address or domain), enables or disables whether Amazon SES forwards bounce and complaint notifications as email. Feedback forwarding can only be disabled when Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) topics are specified for both bounces and complaints.

This action is throttled at one request per second.

For more information about using notifications with Amazon SES, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

required.name: _siffeIdentity
required.documentation: The identity for which to set bounce and complaint notification forwarding. Examples: user@example.com, example.com.

required.name: _siffeForwardingEnabled
required.documentation: Sets whether Amazon SES will forward bounce and complaint notifications as email. true specifies that Amazon SES will forward bounce and complaint notifications as email, in addition to any Amazon SNS topic publishing otherwise specified. false specifies that Amazon SES will publish bounce and complaint notifications only through Amazon SNS. This value can only be set to false when Amazon SNS topics are set for both Bounce and Complaint notification types.

fields.name: _siffeForwardingEnabled
fields.documentation: Sets whether Amazon SES will forward bounce and complaint notifications as email. true specifies that Amazon SES will forward bounce and complaint notifications as email, in addition to any Amazon SNS topic publishing otherwise specified. false specifies that Amazon SES will publish bounce and complaint notifications only through Amazon SNS. This value can only be set to false when Amazon SNS topics are set for both Bounce and Complaint notification types.

fields.name: _siffeIdentity
fields.documentation: The identity for which to set bounce and complaint notification forwarding. Examples: user@example.com, example.com.

operations.name: SetIdentityNotificationTopic
operations.documentation:
Given an identity (email address or domain), sets the Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) topic to which Amazon SES will publish bounce, complaint, and/or delivery notifications for emails sent with that identity as the Source.

This action is throttled at one request per second.

For more information about feedback notification, see the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

required.name: _sintIdentity
required.documentation: The identity for which the Amazon SNS topic will be set. Examples: user@example.com, example.com.

required.name: _sintNotificationType
required.documentation: The type of notifications that will be published to the specified Amazon SNS topic.

optional.name: _sintSnsTopic
optional.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Amazon SNS topic. If the parameter is omitted from the request or a null value is passed, SnsTopic is cleared and publishing is disabled.

fields.name: _sintIdentity
fields.documentation: The identity for which the Amazon SNS topic will be set. Examples: user@example.com, example.com.

fields.name: _sintNotificationType
fields.documentation: The type of notifications that will be published to the specified Amazon SNS topic.

fields.name: _sintSnsTopic
fields.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Amazon SNS topic. If the parameter is omitted from the request or a null value is passed, SnsTopic is cleared and publishing is disabled.

field.name: _vddrDkimTokens
field.documentation:
A set of character strings that represent the domain's identity. If the identity is an email address, the tokens represent the domain of that address.

Using these tokens, you will need to create DNS CNAME records that point to DKIM public keys hosted by Amazon SES. Amazon Web Services will eventually detect that you have updated your DNS records; this detection process may take up to 72 hours. Upon successful detection, Amazon SES will be able to DKIM-sign emails originating from that domain.

For more information about creating DNS records using DKIM tokens, go to the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

optional.name: _vddrDkimTokens
optional.documentation:
A set of character strings that represent the domain's identity. If the identity is an email address, the tokens represent the domain of that address.

Using these tokens, you will need to create DNS CNAME records that point to DKIM public keys hosted by Amazon SES. Amazon Web Services will eventually detect that you have updated your DNS records; this detection process may take up to 72 hours. Upon successful detection, Amazon SES will be able to DKIM-sign emails originating from that domain.

For more information about creating DNS records using DKIM tokens, go to the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

fields.name: _vddrDkimTokens
fields.documentation:
A set of character strings that represent the domain's identity. If the identity is an email address, the tokens represent the domain of that address.

Using these tokens, you will need to create DNS CNAME records that point to DKIM public keys hosted by Amazon SES. Amazon Web Services will eventually detect that you have updated your DNS records; this detection process may take up to 72 hours. Upon successful detection, Amazon SES will be able to DKIM-sign emails originating from that domain.

For more information about creating DNS records using DKIM tokens, go to the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

operations.name: VerifyDomainDkim
operations.documentation:
Returns a set of DKIM tokens for a domain. DKIM tokens are character strings that represent your domain's identity. Using these tokens, you will need to create DNS CNAME records that point to DKIM public keys hosted by Amazon SES. Amazon Web Services will eventually detect that you have updated your DNS records; this detection process may take up to 72 hours. Upon successful detection, Amazon SES will be able to DKIM-sign email originating from that domain.

This action is throttled at one request per second.

To enable or disable Easy DKIM signing for a domain, use the SetIdentityDkimEnabled action.

For more information about creating DNS records using DKIM tokens, go to the Amazon SES Developer Guide.

field.name: _vddDomain
field.documentation: The name of the domain to be verified for Easy DKIM signing.

required.name: _vddDomain
required.documentation: The name of the domain to be verified for Easy DKIM signing.

fields.name: _vddDomain
fields.documentation: The name of the domain to be verified for Easy DKIM signing.

field.name: _vdirVerificationToken
field.documentation: A TXT record that must be placed in the DNS settings for the domain, in order to complete domain verification.

required.documentation: A TXT record that must be placed in the DNS settings for the domain, in order to complete domain verification.

operations.name: VerifyDomainIdentity
operations.documentation:
Verifies a domain.

This action is throttled at one request per second.

required.name: _vdiDomain
required.documentation: The domain to be verified.

fields.name: _vdiDomain
fields.documentation: The domain to be verified.

operations.name: VerifyEmailAddress
operations.documentation:
Verifies an email address. This action causes a confirmation email message to be sent to the specified address.

The VerifyEmailAddress action is deprecated as of the May 15, 2012 release of Domain Verification. The VerifyEmailIdentity action is now preferred.

This action is throttled at one request per second.

required.name: _veaEmailAddress
required.documentation: The email address to be verified.

fields.name: _veaEmailAddress
fields.documentation: The email address to be verified.

operations.name: VerifyEmailIdentity
operations.documentation:
Verifies an email address. This action causes a confirmation email message to be sent to the specified address.

This action is throttled at one request per second.

required.name: _veiEmailAddress
required.documentation: The email address to be verified.

fields.name: _veiEmailAddress
